posts.name: Benjamin Rowe
posts.cooked:
Hello! I’m having an issue with my Swerve drive program, my setup is Neo/Neo/CANCoder/NavX with SDS Mk4s and when I enable all four of my swerve modules just spin (the steering motors) in seemingly random directions at seemingly random speeds. All of the setpoints on the dashboard read 0, and all four cancoders seem to be supplying values, but they never seem to stop when they actually reach zero. I’m using the YAGSL library and just about the example code they provided, just slightly tweaked/cleaned up a little bit.

Contribute to BenFRC5147/SwerveAttemptYAGSL development by creating an account on GitHub.

Thanks in advance for any advice.

Thank you for using YAGSL! Your encoder pulse per rotation is supposed to be 1 not 42. Neo’s have a built in encoder reading from -1 to 1.

Here is a link to the example configuration in YAGSL-Example for Neo’s too. Most of it matches up already by the looks of it.

main/src/main/deploy/swerve/neo

Yet Another General Swerve Library Example Project

posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked:
I can’t say that I know the code base, but as some general troubleshooting steps I guess I’d ask:

Do you know your swerve modules were put together right? Are the magnets superglued in tight for the cancoder?

Using shuffleboard or smart dashboard I suggest you read the voltages being supplied to all of the motors and where they think they are.

I would ensure that your PID loops are continuous, so that when you roll over from 0-360 you aren’t getting a spike in error that could potentially result in a feedback loop like you are seeing.

I would also read the value from the navx to ensure that it is reporting correctly

posts.name: Benjamin Rowe
posts.cooked: This stopped the spinning issue, now they all come to a point and if I try to move them they hold that point, but none of them are the measured offsets lol. One is close frontleft is a few degrees from where it should be, but the reset are all wonky by around 45-135 degrees,

Are your magnets glued in for the CANCoder? Also try making the offsets negative.

As a PSA the online vendordep wont be that reliable for now. Any updates I make I just overwrite the current version currently since it is in beta so you will not be getting updates unless you periodically uninstall then reinstall with the url. I would recommend you copy the swervelib folder into your java folder instead for this reason and update that as you see fit. For reference I have a very similar configuration on my teams robot currently and it is in an acceptable state right now even with an outdated version (i updated the telemetry and removed the cube’d inputs). So your robot should just need some adjustments.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: for falcon/falcon/cancoder what would the encoderPulsePerRotation be ?
For falcon/falcon/cancoder it should be 2048 for both of them.

posts.name: Benjamin Rowe
posts.cooked:
Who would’ve guessed, but my measurements were wrong. I was told the magnets were glued in, and unless the values change, I’m inclined to believe it. Thanks for the pointers!

Will probably follow your advice for the vendordep when I try and make a less copy/pasted program lol. Thanks!

posts.name: Floyd Moore
posts.cooked:
We are also struggling with configuring YAGSL.  We are running SDS 4i modules with NEO motors and CTRE encoders attached to the duty-cycle input on the SparkMax.  From the dashboards and other experiments we have done:

We know the motors all work and the CAN addresses are correct and we can see the internal relative encoders,

We know the motors all work and the CAN addresses are correct and we can see the internal relative encoders,

We can read values from our CTRE absolute encoders.  The output natively 0.0 → 1.0 for a full rotation as read on either the REV utility, or on the dashboard.  We are using the ‘attached’ encoder type in the module json files.

We can read values from our CTRE absolute encoders.  The output natively 0.0 → 1.0 for a full rotation as read on either the REV utility, or on the dashboard.  We are using the ‘attached’ encoder type in the module json files.

We are using the 2023 YAGSL library (from the BroncoBot example). 4) We use a NavX attached to the RoboRio for rotation feedback.

We are using the 2023 YAGSL library (from the BroncoBot example). 4) We use a NavX attached to the RoboRio for rotation feedback.

We are trying to use the Neo configuration from the release to set up our JSON files. https://github.com/BroncBotz3481/YAGSL/tree/main/deploy

We are trying to use the Neo configuration from the release to set up our JSON files. https://github.com/BroncBotz3481/YAGSL/tree/main/deploy

The simulation seems to work fine.  We can drive the robot around the simulated field with no issues.

The simulation seems to work fine.  We can drive the robot around the simulated field with no issues.

When we enable the robot, the modules start spinning around and don’t stop.  We are getting frustrated as we have tried changing a number of the variables and nothing seems to have any effect.  We are assuming (for lack of any concrete data) that our configuration (and especially the absolute encoder feedback) is having issues.

Does anyone have any hints on where to look?  What data should we be looking at on the robot to help diagnose the problem?

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked:
You will have to do an adjustment with your NavX but that shouldn’t cause all the modules to spin around. Have you tried inverting the motors or the encoder or both?

For the NavX you’ll just need to adjust the NavX IMU java file as such https://github.com/Trial-N-Terror-FRC-7900/YAGSL-Max-Swerve-Example/blob/main/src/main/java/swervelib/imu/NavXSwerve.java

posts.name: Floyd Moore
posts.cooked: I thought that the YAGSL NavX gyro configuration took care of this?

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked:
There’s a bug unfortunately, NavX Quaternion Units

I just recommend multiplying by 0.5 for now until there’s a better fix

@Technologyman00 found a bug in NavX which will be fixed in Studica’s 2024 release that YAGSL will use. Unfortunately for now the change is necessary. I do not know if i will upstream the patch as it will be fixed by the 2024 season.

Are your encoders attached using the REV Alternate encoder expansion board or a custom soluti6 which mimics it?

I just updated YAGSL so you have to input your own conversion factors too. I will release a spreadsheet that will calculate the conversion factors, coupling factors, and vision standard deviation formula later this week hopefully. Check out the new configurator at YAGSL Tuning Webpage . It may help!
